name: Digital Wallets
description: This test evaluates your knowledge of crypto wallets, asymmetric (or public-key) cryptography and how those are used within the context of blockchains.
info: WARNING: The keys and seed phrases used in this quiz are purely for educational purposes. Never share, copy/paste or use your keys and seed phrases publicly, unless you know what you're doing! Check out the security page at https://ethereum.org/en/security/ for more information.

questions.title: What is a wallet?
answers: An account that protects my digital assets
A device with RFID technology
An app that proves my identity to the blockchain
An app that is connected to the blockchain to be able to accept transactions

questions.title: Which of the following statements about seed phrases (sometimes also called 'mnemonic', 'secret words' or 'recovery phrase') is true?
answers: Its a series of words that allow access to a crypto wallet
A single phrase allows to generate a large amount of deterministic keys
They leave less room for human error when it comes to backup and recovery
Each word of the secret phrase is selected from a limited dictionary of 2048 words (BIP39)
All of the above
None of the above

questions.title: What happens if you lose access to your secret seed phrase or private key?
answers: You can generate a new key from your corresponding public key
You can request a new key from the network's validators
You lose access and ownership of any assets belonging to the key
You can contact support to recover your funds

questions.title: When signing data, what do you use your private key for?
answers: Encrypt data so others can verify it using your private key
Generate a cryptographic signature with the private key of the recipient
Generate a cryptographic signature that others can verify using your public key
Encrypt a cryptographic signature which is shared along with your private key in the key registry

questions.title: Every transaction on a blockchain is signed using
answers: A smart contract
The private key of the person who sends the transaction
The public key of the person who will receive the transaction
OAuth 2.0 credentials

questions.title: If you send a transaction by mistake, it can be reversed when
answers: You cancel before the next block is created
You pay for the cancellation fee
You request a cancellation from the master node
It can't be reversed

questions.title: You can use the same set of keys to sign any arbitrary (non-transaction) message
answers: True
False

questions.title: What is true about public addresses on Ethereum?
answers: They are used as public identifiers for accounts
The public address is used to sign your transactions
They protect my digital assets
You should never share this with anyone

questions.title: A wallet and an account on Ethereum are the same thing
answers: True
False

questions.title: The types of accounts on Ethereum are
answers: All the same
User accounts and admin accounts
Permissionless accounts and permissioned accounts
Externally-Owned-Accounts and Contract Accounts

questions.title: Which of the following statements about Ethereum's Digital Signature Algorithms are true?
answers: They are generated using a Elliptic Curve Digital Signing Algorithm (ECDSA)
The development of quantum computers could break its security model in the future
The 3 components of the digital signature consist out of `v,r,s`
Ethereum uses the same, SECP256K1, elliptic curve as Bitcoin
All of the above
None of the above

questions.title: Which of the following is a valid Ethereum public key?
answers: 0xd8da6bf26964af9d7eed9e03e53415d37aa96045
All of the above
None of the above

questions.title: What is a transaction nonce?
answers: A hash that proves that the amount of computation is higher than the current difficulty level of the block
A value equal to the number of transactions sent by the sender
A value that corresponds to the amount of gas that needs be paid in Gwei
A hash of the transaction data signed by the sender

questions.title: A transaction in Ethereum is defined as a RLP-encoded message. Which of the following is never part of the transaction envelope?
answers: The gas limit
The 3 components of an ECDSA digital signature
The transaction nonce
The transaction value
The address of the receiver
The address of the sender
